title: 103_s1269
content: The "School Lunch Protection Act of 1993" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress finds an alarming number of instances of price-fixing and bid-rigging in food purchases for school lunch and breakfast programs. The Antitrust Division has filed numerous criminal cases related to bid-rigging conspiracies and similar activities involving dairy products sold to schools or the Department of Defense. Multiple grand juries in States are also investigating these activities. The Antitrust Division has prosecuted numerous cases of bid-rigging and price-fixing in food purchases for school programs, resulting in convictions and fines totaling $100 million. Despite this, the Secretary of Agriculture has not taken action against convicted dairy companies and individuals involved in bid-rigging for school contracts. Effective education and monitoring programs can help prevent such activities in the future. Reducing bid-rigging in school lunch programs can save millions of dollars annually for school districts, parents, and taxpayers. The Comptroller General of the United States recommends bid-rigging awareness training as an effective deterrent. A General Accounting Office report addresses concerns about bid rigging in the school lunch program. SEC. 25. DUTIES OF THE SECRETARY RELATING TO ANTICOMPETITIVE ACTIVITIES. The National School Lunch Act is amended to include new duties for the Secretary regarding anticompetitive activities. The Secretary is required to provide advice, training, and guidance on preventing anticompetitive activities in acquiring commodities for various food programs under the National School Lunch Act. The Secretary must cooperate with the Attorney General and State attorneys general on investigations related to anticompetitive activities in acquiring commodities for food programs. They are also responsible for providing training and guidance to prevent bid-rigging and price-fixing, and have the authority to debar or suspend individuals involved in such activities. The Secretary may request assistance from the food service management institute for carrying out duties related to food programs. Funding of at least \1/2\ of 1 percent of funds for Food and Nutrition Service expenses is required annually. The authority provided by this section will terminate on September 30, 1999. SEC. 4. NONPROCUREMENT DEBARMENT. The National School Lunch Act is amended by inserting a new section titled "SEC. 12A. NONPROCUREMENT DEBARMENT." The Secretary can debar a person, and their affiliates, from supplying products to schools participating in certain programs if convicted of wrongdoing. The Secretary can debar a person, their affiliates, or school district consortium from supplying products if convicted of anticompetitive activities, fraud, false statements, or obstruction of justice. Subsequent convictions result in a minimum 3-year debarment. The Secretary has the authority to debar individuals or entities from supplying products to schools or Federal agencies if convicted of certain offenses. Waivers for debarment may be granted under specific circumstances to prevent adverse effects on competition or procurement capabilities. The Secretary has the authority to debar individuals or entities from supplying products to schools or Federal agencies if convicted of certain offenses. Debarment shall not diminish the authority of government agencies or courts to penalize or punish individuals or affiliates. Regulations will be issued to implement this section. The Secretary of Agriculture shall amend regulations to conform with the National School Lunch Act. Additionally, a consistent debarment policy will be advised to Congress and the Comptroller General within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Agriculture will maintain their authority to debar or suspend individuals from federal assistance programs, as outlined in the National School Lunch Act. Congress and the Comptroller General will be advised on the importance of a consistent debarment policy under federal acquisition and nonprocurement regulations. The Secretary may debar or suspend a person from Federal assistance and benefits for specified causes as outlined in regulations. SEC. 26 of the National School Lunch Act addresses the prevention and control of anticompetitive activities. The Secretary provides financial assistance and support to prevent anticompetitive activities in school lunch, breakfast, milk, and summer food programs. Information on administration can be requested by Congress committees. Authorization of $4,000,000 annually for programs to prevent anticompetitive activities in school meal programs.
